recordings.loc: Sunrise, Mount Rainier, Pierce County, Washington
recordings.rmk: Recording is m4a to mp3 conversion from iPhone video.  Birds were singing from scattered stands of subalpine spruce and fir above the head of Berkeley Park, just north of the junction of the Wonderland and Berkeley Park trails.  About 6300 ft elevation, full overcast, light rain.  This is a fairly open area, subalpine grading to alpine terrain.  I heard several birds singing (3 or more) and one perched briefly in the open, on a low treetop, before flying into a thicket.  I began recording at 16:45.

Geophony: Okanogan highlands, mixed lodgepole pine, subalpine larch, and subalpine fir intermixed with subalpine sagebrush meadow, rolling mountain hills

recordings.loc: Skamania County, Washington
recordings.rmk:
An excerpt from a longer soundscape. I'd been hearing Hermit Thrushes in the distance throughout the morning as I sat listening, but after many hours of patient listening, one lone male decided to land nearby and deliver this beautiful song.

It begins with a few short announcement chirps, but then launches into song, varying in volume based on what I assume is the direction he is facing relative to the mics.

Geophony: high canopy wind through tall Douglas and Grand Firs, slight distant water wash from a meltwater some distance away.

Temperature: ~77° F

Down-mixed to stereo from a Double Mid-Side original, the only modification to this recording is a slight gain boost (+3dB).

recordings.loc: Oxford, Lafayette County, Mississippi
recordings.rmk:
Natural sound. Scream-like call at 0:01, 0:05, 0:09, etc. Bird was calling from deep within the forest understory under mixed hardwood.

#Habitat#
29-acre estate centrally located in Oxford, MS consisting of antebellum home surrounded by lawns and adjacent forest. Privet hedges and small thickets divide the grounds into distinct lawn units. Bordered on all sides by mature oak-hickory forest. Forest edge consists of oak spp, hickory spp, red cedar, mulberry, with understory along the edge dominated by privet (Ligustrum sp.). Grounds around the house include isolated trees and manicured hedges. A path from the end of the parking area leads northward ~1 km through the forest to the northern edge of the property abutting the University of Mississippi campus

#Editing#
Edited in Adobe Audition. Butterworth high-pass filter, order 3, cutoff frequency 1000 Hz

#Equipment#
Fostex FR-2 digital recorder with Sennheiser microphone and Telinga pro 22" parabolic reflector.

recordings.loc: Oxford, Lafayette County, Mississippi
recordings.rmk:
Natural sound. Bird was moving around in privet approx 5m from microphone. Calls apparently directed at me.

#Habitat#
Along the forest edge. State waterfowl refuge along the margins of USACE flood control reservoir. Strip along the lake margins ~1km wide of moist soil grassland with mix of forbs, native warm season grasses (Andropogon, Schyzachyrium, Eragrostis, Aristida, etc.), and some sparse woody vegetation (Cephalanthus, Quercus saplings, etc.) bounded by oak hickory forest and, in places, pine plantation.  Three or four shallow waterfowl impoundments partially flooded in the winter.

#Editing#
Adobe Audition. Butterworth band-pass filter, cutoff 500 hz/5000hz, order 3

#Equipment#
Fostex FR-2 digital recorder with Sennheiser microphone and Telinga pro 22" parabolic reflector.

recordings.rmk: Male on territory about 300 meters down from the trail head in mixed fir and deciduous forest. After playback this bird circled me for a while flying from fir to fir singing from time to time then settled into a normal rhythm in the fir trees. Same bird as XC138239. img:http://www.flickr.com/photos/madbirder/9033173363/

recordings.loc: Cherohala Skyway, Huckleberry Knob, Nantahala National Forest, North Carolina
recordings.rmk: Believe this to be the same male I've had here since 2009, not sure if he's ever had a mate but he's been at this territory for too long not to. You'd think he'd move on if he had no luck. Song structure hasn't changed much. Heard him singing when we got to his territory but on the far side of it. I used playback of one of his previous years songs and he came in to investigate then moved off back into the open birch woodland where he began to sing again. I followed him in recording as I went so the recording sounds soft at first though he's never been a loud singer but as I was able to get a bit closer his song became louder as he got into the act of singing. Though never more that 100 meters from me he didn't really lay into his song till near the end. img:http://www.flickr.com/photos/madbirder/8991070572/
